Deep in the north, where chilling frosts enchain,</br>In adamantine bands the restless deep,</br>Where summer suns exert their pow'r in vain,</br>Where howling tempests o'er the desarts sweep,</br>And snows on snows aloft in drear confusions heap—

Where the hills groan beneath a world of ice,</br>Accumulated from creation's day,</br>And seem to prop the vast incumbent skies,</br>While glittering to the sun's enfeebled ray,</br>And various shapes fantastic to the view display—

Where o'er the fields, o'erwhelmed with ice and snow,</br>The anxious eye for ever roams in vain,</br>In search of flow'rs, which in the meadows glow</br>In climes that boast bright summer's friendly reign;</br>Or ample rivers rolling gently to the main—

Where no fair groves, array'd in cheerful green,</br>Their waving summits to the eye display;</br>No murm'ring brooks, or silv'ry streams are seen,</br>No warbling songster "hops from spray to spray,"</br>To cheer the lab'ring swain with its melodious lay—

Where to the brave, adven'trous mar'ner's view,</br>Huge piles of ice in threat'ning forms appear,</br>While lofty mountains clad with glist'ning snow,</br>Their craggy tops amidst the black clouds rear,</br>While the fierce whirlwind's awful note assails his ear—

There, reigns a pow'r despotic, whose command</br>The wintry blasts, and snows, and frosts obey;</br>Who o'er the deeps extends his frigid hand,</br>And in their rapid course the billows stay,</br>Enchain'd in hardest forms, stopt on their headlong way.
———*———*———*———*———*———

As late in sleep my weary eyes were seal'd,</br>To these dread realms methought I was convey'd,</br>From waking eyes by nature's hand conceal'd</br>Creative fancy to my view display'd</br>Stern, awful, frowning WINTER, terribly array'd.

High on a mountain, whose enormous brow,</br>Soar'd far beyond the scope of human eye,</br>Enwrap'd in clouds, cloth'd with eternal snow,</br>His awful throne, capt by the inclement sky,</br>Stood glitt'ring to the view in awful majesty.

A sable cloud enwrapt his gloomy form,</br>An icy empire fill'd his chilly hand,</br>Around him rear'd the hoarse resounding storm,</br>And all the winds of heav'n (a sullen band)</br>Assembled by their king, stood waiting his command.

When, in a voice that shook the hills around,</br>Thus he the fierce and gloomy band address'd:</br>"Go forth ye pow'rs, and bind in frosts the ground,</br>Ye snows o'erwhelm the earth's late fertile breast,</br>Behold our reign begins, — all nature's works lay waste:

"Make the wide world your notes tremendous hear,</br>The groaning woods hurl prostrate on the plain;</br>Make the vast hills convulsed quake with fear,</br>And in its course arrest the foaming main—</br>Spread 'o'er th' astonish'd world' the terrors of our reign."

'Tis done — behold the fertile fields no more</br>Their beauteous, joy-inspiring liv'ries wear,</br>Silence reigns thro' the groves, where oft before</br>The voice of music met th' enraptur'd ear—</br>But now, alas!  all stript of verdure they appear.

How sad the change! — behold the drifted snow</br>The trees oppress where foliage erst was seen;</br>Enwrapt in frost appears the cheerless bough,</br>All nature mourns with sad dejected mien,</br>And all around presents a cold a dreary scene.

Nought now is heard save the rude whirlwind's roar,</br>Which pours its dismal clamors thro' the vale,</br>Or waves that dash against the frozen shore,</br>Or the loud rattling of the gelid hail,</br>Or the poor shiv'ring brute's loud and discordant wail.

Yon stream which flow'd in majesty along</br>In winter's cold unfeeling arms is bound,</br>The brook that murmur'd to the milk-maid's song,</br>And spread its humid influence around,</br>Now stands immovable, fix'd as the frozen ground.

See o'er the hard smooth surface of the ice,</br>On sounding steel the fearless skater glides;</br>Swift as the meteor darts along the skies,</br>The cheerful nymph along the glib ice slides</br>And jeers the timid swain who in the cot abides.

The merry sleighers hold their rapid course,</br>O'er the white surface of the snowy plain,</br>The cracking whip impels the foaming horse,</br>The lively fiddler plays a merry strain,</br>And warm with gen'rous wine fears neither care nor pain.

With fearful haste the timid rabbits fly,</br>While in the snow the swains their footsteps trace,</br>The track pursue, the panting game descry,</br>And yelping hounds join in the eager chace—</br>While chearful, rosy health glows in the hunter's face.

See the storm gathers in the threat'ning sky,</br>A dark and dreary horror spreads around,</br>The north wind lifts its awful voice on high</br>Roars thro' the vales and makes the hills resound;</br>Thick [falls?] the drifting snow, and overwhelms the ground.

Loud howls the tempest o'er the bois'trous deep,</br>The shiv'ring sailor shrinks before the blast,</br>The foaming billows o'er his vessel sweep,—</br>Now rais'd on high, now in an abyss vast,</br>(Chill'd by the piercing cold) the hapless wretch is cast.

While all is wrapp'd in night's terrific gloom,</br>No friendly ray of light assails his eyes,</br>The trackless ocean, (that tremendous tomb</br>Where many a wretch in death's cold slumber lies)</br>Embraces in its bill'wy arms the hapless prize.

Oh Thou GREAT POW'R, who rul'st the bois'rous main,</br>"Rid'st in the whirlwind and directs the storm,"</br>Who seest the poor storm-beaten sailor's pain,</br>O save him, save him from impending harm,</br>Lull the destructive tempest, and its rage disarm.
———*———*———*———*———*———

Return my muse, to the warm cheerful fire,</br>Where safe, I can the raging storm defy,</br>Where peace and comfort, cheerfulness inspire,</br>And social friends the passing hours enjoy</br>In conversation sweet, in bliss without alloy:

Or listen to the legendary tale,</br>Of ghosts that wander mid' the gloom of night,</br>Of shadowy heroes, cloth'd in coats of mail,</br>Who bravely perish'd in the bloody fight,</br>And on th' ensanguin'd plain oft meet the wand'rer's sight—

Of love-lorn swains, whose grisly spectres fly,</br>In some lone wood athwart the midnight gloom,</br>And often meet the affrighted fair one's eye,</br>Whose cruel scorn has doom'd them to the tomb,</br>To bury all their sorrows in the earth's cold womb—

Or wither'd witches riding through the air,</br>While close together croud the simple crew,</br>And seiz'd with sudden fear begin to stare,</br>And think to see a meagre ghost appear,</br>When the loud howling of the furious storm they hear.

But rather would I seek the social friend,</br>Whose heart is honest, and inform'd his mind,</br>Or the gay circle of the fair attend,</br>And from my brow the wreaths of care unbind,</br>And with delighted eyes, see charms and sense combin'd—

Or listen to the soothing voice of song,</br>Which to the heart resistless makes its way,</br>Melodious strains by angel-voices sung,</br>To pity, sooth, or melt in love away,</br>And ev'n to savage hearts emotions soft convey.

And now while angry winter scowls around,</br>While plenty fills your overflowing store;</br>Full many a wretch uncumber'd woes surround,</br>Sick, friendless, houseless, feeble, old and poor,</br>Condemn'd to supplicate for bread from door to door.

Let gentle pity warm the feeling heart,</br>And let not av'rice the small boon deny,</br>To the poor suff'rer ev'ry aid impart,</br>Wipe the sad tear from mis'ry's pallid eye,</br>And spread around you, plenty, happiness and joy.</br>
